Me and my 6 friends went on holiday to Mallorca. One morning we decided to rent a boat and have a small trip around the coast. Fortunately during the trip waves were big enough to soak everyone's back packs with water. Because my phone is like 2 months old, I decided to hold it in my hand instead of wet back pack. Middle day the see started going crazy and at some point waves started getting  inside our boat. We immediately tried to get back to the closest shore but... It was too late. Lots of water got on board. We had to jump out and seconds later boat was upside down. We were too far from the shore to just swim, but luckily for us, boat was still floating on water so we had something to grab to. I was the only one who still had phone in the hand. I climbed on the boat and started calling help. 1 mile from shore. Open see. Absolutely wet - this phone managed to give me a 10 minutes call to 112, connect with them via what'sapp and send them our live location. 30 minutes later we have been picked by rescue boat. If that phone wouldn't be waterproof, or just break down idk what would happen to me and 6 of my friends. Did I mention that idk how to swim?

Great phone fabulous camera.

Butter smooth performance and eye catching display.

While the Galaxy S20, with its elongated display and compact size, is more suitable for people with small hands, the Galaxy S20 + is larger and wider, which means it will appeal to fans of huge diagonals. Interestingly, at 188 grams, it is much lighter than the Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max. The smartphone fits well in the hand and surprises with a small thickness of 7.8 mm. True, the rear camera module still protrudes noticeably from the body.

A protective Gorilla Glass 6 is installed on both sides of the case, which surpasses the previous version in strength. Despite Samsung's tweaks of beautiful gradients, the smartphone is quickly covered in fingerprints and smudges. The front and rear panels are connected by a metal frame, the joints are smooth and invisible. The build quality is excellent.

The smartphone is protected from dust and moisture according to the IP68 standard, so you can not be afraid of rain.

I was initially hesitant to buy this phone with the screen being 6.7 inches however the tiny bezels all around make it the perfect size for my hands and pockets. The 120 Hz refresh rate makes scrolling, animations and gameplay super smooth and not jittery - once you try it you'll realise how slick it is. It's really quick installing/opening apps and updates. One feature that I really didn't give too much through to when buying this phone was how rapidly it charges! It has super fast charging so a 30 min charge adds around 50% more battery which is really convenient when you need a quick top up. It has 4 cameras -  main, telephoto, ultra wide and one for portrait shots (blur) which produce beautiful photos and videos. And it's 5G capable so it's future proof too. 

In the past Samsung had a poor track record with security updates but now they're really swift, and even quicker than Google in some instances. 
The new 'One UI 2' user interface makes navigation easy and effortless. It's really light and not at all cluttered like the dark TouchWiz days *shiver*. Owning a Samsung since the Galaxy S3 I can attest to how far Samsung has come.
If you own other Samsung products you will appreciate how seamless it is interacting with them. It takes mere seconds to cast my phone to my TV to watch a video or mirror my screen with the connection being stable. 

If you're still deliberating, definitely go with the S20+ - you won't be disappointed!

I'm using Samsung smart phones for years. I had Galaxy 2, 4, 6, 9 and finally 20+. So far this is definitely the best one. Screen is amazing, very sharp and responsive. Battery life is surprising. I'm not one of those who plays with the phone all day long but I check my phone fairly often. It takes me two full days to drain the battery. My previous phone (S9) was always below 25% by 8pm everyday.  S20+ looks massive when you check it online but it's not ridiculous. Still fits in the pocket and not awkward to use. Performance is also really good. Never slows down or struggle. There are minor issues I should mention. Fingerprint scanner isn't as responsive as S9, but it's not bad. Still works and does the job. Maybe S9's one was too good (even though the location was weird...). Second minor issues is camera focus. Occasionally it was a having trouble to set the focus correctly but with the last updates it works better. Also I find the colours of the pictures slightly more red/orange compared to others. I added 2 pictures, took a picture of the same chip with S9 and S20. You can do your own judgement. Overall I really like the S20+ and I'd definitely recommend it.

I've had Samsung Galaxy phones since the S3 and purchased the S20+ 5G as part of my contract renewal.
My overall impression is that the phone's okay but not much of an upgrade on my S9 and in some ways it's not as good.
Pros:
- Nice screen
- The S20+ size is about spot on
- Seems well built
- 120hz refresh rate is smooth

Cons:
- The camera is poor: auto focus is all over the place, especially for close shots. Pro mode is a bit better but to be honest I expected more. Maybe a few software updates will fix it. As for picture quality my 5 year old Sony digital camera absolutely slaughters it as far as I'm concerned.
- Smart Lock doesn't work: Smart lock on my S9 was hit and miss but in the main worked quite well, on the S20+ it's simply broken.
- Google Chrome constantly freezes to such an extent it's useless. 
- Finger print sensor is nowhere near as good as it should be, which is a shame given how much I need to use it due to the problems with smart lock.

To be honest I'd have been better off keeping my S9 on a sim only deal until such time the S20+ gets its flaws sorted out, which hopefully can be done with future software updates.

The device runs very smoothly, and it looks absolutely stunning. The camera is great too as long as it's not a close up.

Battery-This is my bigger issue and concern. I am coming from an S10 and battery life was average. I always had to charge my phone before leaving work at 5pm. I use my phone a lot therefore I was getting 4-5 SOT. Was decent. I bought the S20+ because, bigger phone, bigger battery. I have to say that I am deeply disappointed. I still have to charge my phone before I leave work which is big blow for me. I recently switched to 60hz from 120hz. Battery life is the same. Literally no difference. I don't game a lot, I only use my phone for browsing and messaging with friends. No heavy gaming sessions, no all day video streaming, no music. Just chat and forums and that’s about it. Again, I cannot stress enough how terrible the battery life is. 

Performance-Being in the UK means that I am on Exynos processor which again it is a blow. I don't game a lot but when I do, I play 10-15 minutes of Call of Duty and boy this phone gets hot. After 5-10 minutes of use I feel the phone heating so much that I need to stop. I feel that is going to explode. I don't get it. We pay the same price, even more if you convert. Why are we getting an inferior phone? Do we not matter to you? If the fruit would have come with and USB-C port phone I would have switched. I have been an Samsung user since the S7 Edge and had the S8, S9, S10 and now the S20+. I never felt so let down by a phone. It will probably be my last Samsung. Sorry but such a high price for what? Inferior chip and lame battery life. No thank you. 

On the plus side, form factor is great, screen is gorgeous, quality build is good as well. I like how you moved the buttons and still miss the headphone jack (I can't use normal headphones due to the shape of my ears, and regular ones don't fit). Camera is good, I only point and shoot so I’m no expert and was satisfied by camera quality since the S9 so nothing to add here.

In conclusion, is the first Samsung phone that I can't recommend. And not only that, I even tell people to stay away from it. Utterly disappointed...

S20+ is a great all rounder with excellent screen, battery life, camera, and super slick interface.  It is much larger than any phone I have owned previously, but feels much smaller than it is and feels thinner, lighter, and easier to use than I expected.
I upgraded from an S7 and the difference is huge.  The fingerprint scanner works far better than I expected and the facial recognition generally unlocks the phone before I have a chance to use the fingerprint scanner.
The battery lasts easily a day and a half, charges very quickly even with standard fast charger, and I find I don't now have to either charge overnight or switch to maximum power saving mode in the afternoon to get through the day.
One of my main reasons for upgrading my phone was to have a better camera, although I have found that while the camera is very good it is probably not the feature that has impressed me most.

So many things about this phone are great (battery, camera, less curves at the edge of the screen). However there are some things that are far worse - the in-display fingerprint sensor is useless and works 50/50 of the time. The proximity sensor, if there is one, doesn't work very well - unlocks in pockets, when in calls etc.  The edge detection is either too keen or doesnt work at all, especially with gestures turned on.  Finally, the exynos processor - all the reviews come from america where they get the snapdragon, so their battery and performance are so much better than what the exynos users get, so don't expect these to match what you see on the reviews.

I upgraded from an iPhone SE and love my S20+. The phone is feature rich, with a slick OS (OneUI 2) and a gorgeous screen.

I bought the Samsung Galaxy S20+ two weeks ago, upgrading from a Samsung Galaxy S9. I did a lot of research prior to purchasing this phone, taking into account camera quality vs. the Ultra, battery life, performance, and more, which are all important features for me. So far, I have been very impressed!

Firstly, a lot of reviews on here are complaining about auto-focus issues, high battery-drain, especially relating to the UK model, as well as the fingerprint sensor being troublesome. I can honestly say I have hardly experienced any of these problems. 

I am a moderate to heavy user, checking social media regularly, using many apps, playing games, etc. and my battery life has been exceptional. It has lasted me 2 days easily, whereas my S9 was needing a top-up with the same usage by the end of the day at least, and in some cases even earlier. Granted, due to the lockdown measures, I have been on Wi-Fi the whole time and haven't been on a huge amount of walks or adventures, but even when using my phone for GPS during walks and runs and using mobile data, the battery drain has been minimal. There is also no 5G in my area, so have been on 4G. I expect 5G would drain the battery a bit more. 

The camera is slick, responsive and takes great pictures. It is worth noting the 64MP mode is not the default option - this needs to be selected from the top of the camera menu, which was not immediately obvious. The images this camera produces are very crisp and clear, even in low-light. You really can keep pinching in to look at the detail! The default camera mode is also pretty good, but the images are not as crisp as it doesn't necessarily use the 64MP sensor. I chose this phone over the Ultra purely based on the 100x zoom on the Ultra looking like a bit of a gimmick, and it is fair to say the 30x zoom on the S20+ seems pretty unusable unless you have a super steady hand or a tripod. However, it is very impressive how far you can zoom, and I expect if you were photographing something far away, the drop in quality would not be that noticeable.

The display is incredible. I was very surprised with the 120Hz refresh rate - this makes the whole navigation and scrolling experience even better. It does drain the battery a bit quicker though. I really like how the display is flatter - the edges seem a lot sharper, and there have been fewer accidental touches when compared to the waterfall edges on the S9. I can also say the performance has been incredible!

There are only a few slightly negative comments I can make about this phone. The first is the fingerprint sensor. I read many reviews saying it was troublesome, and the first few days, I had no problems. However, after getting used to the phone now, I can say the phone unlocks about 70% of the time with the fingerprint (on the first attempt). Some of this is down to getting to know where to place your finger, as the S9 has a very clear, dedicated area for placing your finger, whereas it is hard to see where on the screen this is without the display helping point you in the right zone. I am sure this will improve with time, but was surprised how fiddly it was to setup well, considering the price. Also, I think it depends how well you program your fingerprint - make sure to roll your finger or thumb around to get the best out of it! The other slightly negative comment is regarding the proximity sensor. On the S9, this was a dedicated sensor, whereas on the S20+, it seems to be in the screen. There is a little blinking pixel near the top of the phone which scared me at first, but it turns out this is the proximity sensor! The reaction to light level for the S20+ is slower and less accurate than the S9, but I'm really clutching at straws here to find some negative comments.

Overall, I am super happy with this phone, and got it at a great price with student discount and trading my S9 in. I hope this review helps you make your all important decision!

Samsung decided to employ ultra-aggressive image processing on the S20 Plus camera. Even if you turn HDR, 'beauty mode' and other image enhancing features OFF, the pictures it creates are still awful. Sharpening and contrast are cranked up to the max and the saturation is turned up sky high. It's not that photos don't look natural, they look ridiculously fake even by the standards of Instagram. The final nail in the coffin for me though was the face smoothing. As I've said above, I turned 'beauty mode' and enhancers off - yet it completely blurs and smooths the skin/surface of whatever face it recognises, whether that's a person or even a pet. I've sent mine back to Samsung and returned to my S8+ that ironically has a vastly superior and sharper camera that captures far more detail and doesn't blur everything into oblivion.

The only issue you I have, & it is a big one,is the fingerprint sensor, is complete rubbish.  I hardly ever works, this is an issue when you consider the money you are spending on a premium phone. Recommend it.
